Hi Sathya,

It is possible that NEAT can help with your problem.  It should=
 be 
able to find an appropriate level of network complexity (i.e. 
topolog=
y and # of hidden neurons) for your problem.  There are 
several ways you c=
ould use NEAT for this task:

1.  Use NEAT for everything:  Evolve with NEA=
T directly both weights 
and topology to best learn the training data.

2. =
Combine NEAT with backpropagation:  In this case, you evolve with 
NEAT, bu=
t each network is evaluated by applying backpropagation on 
the training se=
t to see how good the results are.  Networks 
reproduce that work best with=
 backprop.  In this case, you would a 
semi-optimal backprop topology.  I k=
now people who've done similar 
things with NEAT in the past.

I hope this =
helps provide some insight.  If you feel uncertain about 
the proper neural=
 network topology for a problem, NEAT is a viable 
option for addressing th=
at concern.   Note however that NEAT has not 
been shown to be superior to =
other methods in regular classification 
tasks.  It *may* be better in some=
 cases, but most experiments with 
NEAT have not focused on classification =
from training data (rather, 
NEAT is usually used for control or sequential=
 decision-making), so 
we do not have a substantial record to refer to in t=
his area.

ken

hnamurthy@g...> wrote:

By

l experiments using design of 
> experiments. Using the results I build a n=
eural network model, 
most 
> of the times guessing what the appropriate si=
ze and parameters of 
> the network should be. 
> 
> I do not build the mod=
els incrementally, rather I build them as an 
> one-time affair. The proble=
ms I face are the following:
> 
> Given the number of inputs (x) and the nu=
mber of outputs (y) and 
the 
> size of the training set,I have trouble est=
imating what is the 
> appropriate parameters for building the network? (li=
ke learning 
> rate, size of network, what kind of algorithm etc.)
> 
> Do =
the experts feel that NEAT will be able to answer such queries 
> for me ? =
or can I use NEAT to build models without having to worry 
> about the netw=
ork parameters? or Do I have it completely wrong 
about 
> NEAT?
> 
> Thank=
s for your suggestions.
